header: The Life Cycle of a Learning Activity
content:
Web technology, with its global reach and connective power, is a tool with tremendous potential to change how development work is done. The KDMD project leveraged rapidly evolving web technology on behalf of its USAID partners to build a series of websites and online knowledge sharing portals to jointly create, share, refine, and apply practical approaches to development challenges. As a key element of KDMD’s streamlined web strategy, the project leveraged the work done on previous sites to iteratively develop new functionality, creating flexible web templates on the Drupal platform that were adapted to meet identified user needs.


The earliest sites created by KDMD—including the African Diaspora Marketplace (May 2009), the Economic Growth Learning Center (Jun 2009), and Social Transitions (May 2010)—laid the foundation for the more robust sites that followed. KDMD’s flagship sites that the project continues to manage include the Knowledge-Driven International Development Portal (Jul 2010), Microlinks (Sep 2010), Agrilinks (Nov 2012), WLSME (Nov 2012), and Learning Lab (Jan 2013). In addition, KDMD developed the Caribbean Partners for Educational Progress Community of Practice (formerly Jamaica, Dec 2010) and FeedtheFuture.gov (Nov 2011) websites.


Agrilinks and Learning Lab are perfect examples of how KDMD built upon its web experience to streamline the development process. When the USAID Bureau for Food Security approached KDMD about its web needs, KDMD provided a temporary solution on KDID (Aug 2010) while a robust needs assessment process was conducted. The second iteration of Agrilinks (Apr 2011) was then constructed from the Microlinks Drupal web template and was rigorously tested through user focus groups and member surveys. Finally, the stand-alone Agrilinks (Nov 2012) site was built on the most current version of Drupal (7.0) and incorporated a cleaner design, significantly enhanced functionality, and many more web 2.0 tools. As the project’s most advanced website, Agrilinks then became the template upon which WLSME and Learning Lab—both of which also began as placeholder pages on KDID—were built. This iterative process allowed KDMD to take advantage of lessons learned to advise clients on best practices, ensure the best user experience, and minimize development time/cost.

header: The Life Cycle of a Learning Activity
content:
Learning activities should ideally move through four stages to complete a full life cycle. Each of the stages is important and ensures that key learning from the activity is generated, captured, shared, and applied to meet the goals of the knowledge cycle.


Scoping

Scoping is an essential part of any activity planning. The KDMD project uses scoping to solicit crucial information from a client in order to design an appropriate learning activity. Scoping can be formal or informal and can take place in person, over email, or over the telephone. Depending on the situation, it can consist of one discussion or can be spread out over multiple discussions. Scoping can (and should) take place throughout the entire activity planning process to respond to changing ideas or priorities. It should be a fluid process but one that is ultimately focused on identifying the best options based on key objectives. Once a specific learning activity has been identified, planning for the activity can begin.


Implementing

The implementation stage begins when all of the pre-work of scoping and planning is completed. This stage can involve many steps and moves quickly depending on the learning activity. This is why it is extremely important before the activity begins to put into place the processes and structure which will facilitate coordination among team members. Frequent and transparent communication as well as documentation and delegation of tasks among individuals are vital for the smooth implementation of a learning activity.



Capture and documentation are also essential components of this stage. This can be done in a variety of different ways, from note taking to live webcasting. Regardless of how information is ultimately captured, discussions about this part of the implementation stage should occur during scoping.



Engaging

Once a learning activity has been implemented and key information has been captured, it is important to share out this information so that others may benefit from it. Engagement can range from posting information on websites, to formal post-activity emails, to (in its simplest form) informal conversations about the activity with others. The important point is that the learning activity should not end after implementation. Instead, strategic decisions on how knowledge sharing and learning can be sustained should ideally be considered ahead of time so that new learning is leveraged long after the activity itself is over.


Adapting

The ultimate goal of a learning activity is for the knowledge generated from it to be utilized and applied by others to advance industry practice. Key learning, once it’s shared and accessed, should somehow influence the way that individuals think and act. It should inform approaches and activities going forward to re-imagine and improve how work is done. This adaptation can then be captured and shared the next time that a learning activity life cycle begins.

Over the years, KDMD has managed nine popular seminar series on topics ranging from microfinance to agricultural development. The earliest seminars were small in-person events, but with additional experience, KDMD enhanced the seminar experience in many ways:


Webinars: Using the Adobe Connect platform, KDMD expanded the opportunities for remote participation to reach a truly global audience. The chat feature was particularly effective in fostering robust discussions, especially when staff from presenting organizations were encouraged to participate, answering audience questions and providing their own perspective. KDMD has also used webinars to open up the opportunities for hearing directly from people working on the ground by bringing in remote presenters. To learn more about KDMD’s experience with webinars, check out this guidance brief.


Interactivity: KDMD used audience response technology both through Adobe Connect and Poll Everywhere to poll online and in person seminar participants in real time. Polling frequently helped to guide audience discussion and spark debate on complex issues.


Social Media: KDMD promoted its seminars through Facebook, Twitter, and LinkedIn. Staff tweeted using popular hashtags to maximize visibility and crafted post-event blogs that provided detailed recaps of the seminar presentations.


Participant Feedback: KDMD’s Assessing & Learning team solicited feedback with surveys distributed at the end of every seminar. Attendees were given the opportunity to suggest future event topics and share how they felt they could use the knowledge and resources from the seminar to improve their work.


Post-Event Products: KDMD strove to make all event material easily accessible so learning could continue after the event. Beyond the presentations and other resources shared, events were captured either as screencast or webinar recordings. Staff created blog posts, archived social media posts, and filmed Greenroom Interviews with presenters to compile a rich collection of media.


Enhanced Follow-Up: Finally, KDMD followed up with seminar attendees and other stakeholders through post-event emails with links to relevant resources. KDMD also work with presenters to collect responses to unanswered questions and post them to the relevant online comment board.
